I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Government of Australia, 
to the Republic of Kiribati for the South Tarawa Sanitation Improvement Sector Project. 
 
2. 
South Tarawa comprises a series of islets located along the southern rim of Tarawa Atoll 
with  a  total  land  area  of  under  15  square  kilometers  (km2).  High  population  density,  poor 
hygiene  practices,  and  inadequate  sanitation  infrastructure  have  contributed  to  a  high 
prevalence  of  waterborne  disease  among  the  local  population  and  degradation  of  the  natural 
environment.  The  proposed  project  will  support  improvements  to  the  health  of  communities  in 
South  Tarawa.  This  will  be  achieved  through:  (i)  enhanced  community  engagement  in,  and 
public  awareness  of,  hygiene  and  sanitation;  (ii)  rehabilitation  and  upgrading  of  sanitation 
infrastructure;  (iii)  capacity  development    in  sector  planning,  and  operations  and  maintenance 
(O&M)  of  urban  water  supply  and  sanitation  services;  and  (iv)  the  creation  of  a  sanitation 
maintenance fund to ensure adequate financing for sanitation infrastructure maintenance.1
  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Almost  50%  of  Kiribati’s  population  of  103,466  lives  in  South  Tarawa,  the  country’s 
political and economic center. South Tarawa’s main urban areas of Bairiki, Betio, and Bikenibeu 
have  a  combined  population  of  24,171.  Rapid  urbanization  has  resulted  in  an  annual  average 
population growth rate of 4.4% since 2005. The average population density in South Tarawa is 
4,150  per  km2,  and  it  is  as  high  as  10,610  per  km2  in  the  most  densely  settled  areas. 2  In 
comparison,  in  2010,  Singapore  had  a  population  density  of  7,126  per  km2. 3
  Population 
pressures, combined with uncontrolled urban settlement, have resulted in overcrowding that has 
put stress on critical public infrastructure and the natural environment. 
 
4. 
The infant mortality rate in Kiribati at 46 per 1,000 live births is among the highest in the 
world and can be attributed, in part, to infantile diarrhea.4 Health officials report an average of 
two to three outbreaks of acute diarrheal disease in South Tarawa every year which is directly 
linked  to  inadequate  sanitation  and  poor  hygiene. 5  A  number  of  studies  have  shown  that 
household groundwater wells, lagoon water close to the shoreline, and edible shellfish contain 
high  faecal  coliform  levels. 6  The  dominant  source  of  contamination  is  the  lack  of  adequate 
residential  sanitation  infrastructure.  According  to  2005  census  data,  33%  of  South  Tarawa’s 
households used toilets connected to the sewerage system, 27.3% used flush toilets connected 
to  septic  tanks,  3.7%  used  compost  toilets,  20%  used  the  sea,  29.1%  used  the  beach,  34% 
used pit latrines, and 6.8% used the bush.7

Due  to  a  shortage  of  management  and  technical  skills  and  financial  resources,  the 
5. 
sewerage  system,  operated  by  the  Public  Utilities  Board  (PUB),  is  in  a  severely  dilapidated 
condition. Weak capacity to manage existing sanitation assets and operations among PUB and 
Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Utilities 
to  chronic 
underperformance  of the  sewerage  system.  Sewerage services  are  provided free  of  charge  to 
customers.  O&M  activities  are  funded  through  government  transfers,  while  periodic  capital 
investments  in  system  rehabilitation  and  upgrading  have  been  externally  financed  by 
development partners. The current situation has resulted in low sustainability. In the absence of 
adequate resources, no preventive or routine maintenance is carried out; instead, maintenance 
is deferred until the system fails. This situation imposes high costs on both the government and 
the  local  population  in  terms  of  lost  productivity,  health  expenditures,  and  degradation  of 
freshwater resources and coastal areas. 
 
6. 
The  problem  of  inadequate  sanitation  infrastructure  is  compounded  by  limited  public 
awareness  of  the  links  between  sanitation,  hygiene,  and  health.  Accordingly,  demand  and 
willingness to pay for improved sanitation facilities are low. Households do not perceive the full 
benefits associated with improved sewerage services, nor the large negative externalities linked 
to common behavior such as open defecation and not washing one’s hands. A widespread and 
sustained  public  awareness  and  education  campaign  specifically  targeting  groups  such  as 
women  and  children  is  required  to  bring  about  improved  hygiene  behavior  and  to  create 
demand for improved sanitation. 
 
7. 
The project is consistent with the Kiribati Development Plan, 2008–2011, which commits 
to improving health outcomes, strengthening governance in the provision of public services, and 
investing  in  social  and  economic  infrastructure.  The  project  is  included  in  the  Kiribati  country 
partnership  strategy,  2010–2014,  which  aims  to  reduce  poverty  and  promote  economic 
opportunity  by  improving  the  delivery  of  sustainable  infrastructure  services. 8
  The  project 
supports  the  country’s  National  Sanitation  Policy;  National  Water  Resources  Policy;  and  the 
Government  of  Kiribati’s Water  Supply,  Sanitation,  and  Solid Waste  Management  Program for 
South  Tarawa  that  was  developed  in  2010  with  assistance  from  the  Pacific  Infrastructure 
Advisory Center. This program is intended to support a whole-of-sector approach and promote 
effective coordination of development partner-supported activities in the sector.  
 
8. 
The project meets the criteria for sector financing as (i) the government has prepared a 
water  and  sanitation  program  for  South  Tarawa,  and  a  20-year  water  supply  and  sanitation 
investment roadmap, which provides a comprehensive framework for planning and coordinating 
sector  investments;  (ii)  additional  capacity  development  support  to  the  MPWU  and  PUB 
provided  under  the  project  will  ensure  that  the  government  has  the  institutional  capacity  to  
implement  its  sector  development  plans;  and  (iii)  the  country’s  sector  policies  are  appropriate, 
and assistance provided under the project will support their implementation, including increasing 
access to sanitation and ensuring cost recovery in the delivery of water and sanitation services 
through tariff reform.

B. 
 
10. 
The  impact  of  the  project  is  the  improved  health  of  South  Tarawa’s  population.  The 
outcome  of  the  project  will  be  that  South  Tarawa’s  urban  population  has  enhanced  access  to 
improved sanitation infrastructure and services. 
 
C. 
 
11. 
The project will deliver the following outputs: (i) sanitation and hygiene practices among 
South Tarawa’s population will be improved, (ii) wastewater in South Tarawa will be effectively 
managed  by  PUB,  (iii)  the  MPWU  and  PUB  will  have  the  capacity  to  plan  and  manage  water 
and  sanitation  services,  (iv)  adequate  funds  will  be  available  to  the  PUB  to  finance  sanitation 
O&M, and (v) project management and implementation services by the Ministry of Finance and 
Economic  Development  (MFED)  and  MPWU  will  ensure  efficient  and  effective  project 
implementation.  The  majority  of  project  outputs  will  include  specific  gender  design  features  to 
ensure women’s participation in and access to project benefits. 
 
12. 
Output  1:  Community  engagement.  Sanitation  and  hygiene  practices  among  South 
Tarawa’s population will be improved. A comprehensive and sustained community awareness, 
improve 
education,  and  participation  program  will  be  designed  and 
understanding of the close links among health, hygiene, water use, and sanitation practices at 
the  urban  and  village  household  levels  throughout  South  Tarawa.  Awareness  activities  at  the 
community  level  will  be  delivered  through  community  mobilizers,  engaged  under  the  project, 
who  will  be  trained  in  sanitation  and  hygiene  promotion.  A  culturally  appropriate  media 
campaign  will  also  be  launched. The  community  engagement  and  public  awareness  programs 
will  be  implemented  in  coordination  with  development  partners  including  the  United  Nations 
Children’s Fund (UNICEF), the World Bank, and the New Zealand Aid Programme. 
 
13. 
infrastructure.  Priority  water  and  sanitation 
infrastructure  will  be  upgraded.  High  priority  investments  identified  in  the  water  supply  and 
sanitation  road  map,  2011–2030  were  selected  as  core  subprojects.  These  include  (i) 
rehabilitation  of  the  existing  Bairiki,  Betio,  and  Bikenibeu  sewerage  systems;  (ii)  upgrading 
works  on  three  sewerage  outfalls;  and  (iii) procurement  of  a  sludge  digester  for  septic  tank 
effluent,  and  sewerage  and  septic  tank  cleaning  equipment.  Additional  subprojects  will  be

project. 12
  Investments  in  on-site  sanitation  are  likely  to  be  included  among  additional

 Output  3:  Capacity  building.  The  MPWU and PUB will have the capacity to plan and

manage water and sanitation services. The project will strengthen the MPWU’s capacity to plan 
and  develop  the  sanitation  and  water  supply  sectors.  The  project  will  deliver  training  to  PUB 
staff  in  financial  management  and  O&M  to  ensure  effective  implementation  of  asset 
management plans. The project will also assist with the development and phased introduction of 
an appropriate tariff structure. To address critical skills gaps within the MPWU and PUB, at least 
two staff will be provided with the opportunity to obtain diplomas in engineering. 
 
Output  4:  Sanitation maintenance  fund.  Adequate funds will be available to the PUB 
15. 
to  finance  sanitation  O&M.  A  dedicated  sanitation  maintenance  fund  (SMF)  will  be  created 
under the MPWU to ensure that adequate resources are available to finance O&M activities that 
are  critical  for  the  sustainability  of  infrastructure  investments.  The  SMF  will  initially  be  set  up 
with  $1.4  million  in  grant  funds.  A  tariff  structure  will  be  developed  in  consultation  with  the 
government  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  at  the  beginning  of  the  project 
implementation  period,  and  tariffs  will  be  phased  in  over  the  life  of  the  project.  By  the  end  of 
2018, the PUB will be expected to recover at least 85% of O&M costs through user charges. 
 
16. 
Output 5: Project management. Project management and implementation services by 
the  MFED  and  MPWU  will  ensure  effective  and  efficient  project  implementation.  The  existing 
project  management  unit  (PMU)  established  within  the  MFED  to  oversee  the  ADB-supported 
Kiribati  Road  Rehabilitation  Project13
  will  also  be  responsible  for  overall  project  coordination, 
financial  management,  procurement,  and  project  monitoring  and  reporting.  The  coordination, 
financial  management,  and  procurement  capacity  of  the  PMU  will  be  strengthened  with 
additional  consultant  support  provided  under  the  project.  Consultants  will  assist  in  day-to-day 
administration,  coordination,  financial  management,  and  project  performance  monitoring  and 
reporting. 
 
17. 
A  project  implementation  unit  (PIU)  will  be  established  within  the  MPWU  to  oversee 
project implementation. The PIU will be responsible for (i) civil  works construction supervision; 
(ii) feasibility  assessments  for  appraisal  of  additional  subprojects;  (iii)  detailed  design  of 
additional  subprojects;  (iv)  design,  establishment,  and  management  support  for  the  SMF; 
(v) MPWU  and  PUB  capacity  building  activities;  (vi)  community  engagement  and  public 
awareness  activities;  (vii)  implementation  of  the  gender  action  plan  (GAP);  (viii)  ensuring 
safeguards  compliance; 
to

surveys. The PIU will also assist the PMU in preparing work plans and tender documents, and 
support  the  tender  process,  reporting,  and  other  relevant  tasks.  Consultant  support  will  be 
provided to the PIU to ensure effective project implementation.

Technical  

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
21. 
The design of the project provides for plant, equipment, and mechanical items to be of a 
standard  suitable  for  operation  in  a  saltwater  environment  and  Kiribati’s  harsh  ocean  climate. 
Subproject  engineering  designs  will  take  into  account  the  possible  risks  posed  by  climate 
change  impacts.  The  project  will  utilize  a  seawater  reticulation  system  to  conserve  scarce 
freshwater resources. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
Economic  analysis. The economic internal rate of return is estimated at 16.1%, which 
is  considered  to  be  acceptable  as  it  exceeds  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12% 
adopted for the analysis. The high economic internal rate of return can be attributed to expected 
improvements  in  productivity  resulting  from  reduced  incidences  of  mortality,  particularly  of 
infants  and  children  under  5  years  of  age,  and  from  the  avoided  near-term  risk  of  a  serious 
outbreak of a potentially fatal disease such as cholera. 
 
23. 
Financial sustainability. The financial analysis concluded that the project is both viable 
and sustainable based on the government’s commitment to introduce tariffs to cover sewerage 
O&M costs along with service delivery improvements. The establishment of the SMF will ensure 

 

 Governance 

that  adequate funds  are  available  to  cover  O&M  costs  of the  sanitation system  in  the short  to 
medium term. 
 
C. 
 
24. 
Financial  management.  The  use  of  expenditure  commitment  controls  varies  between 
ministries  but  is  generally  insufficient.  Although  financial  laws  and  regulations  have  been 
updated periodically since their original enactment in the mid-1970s, they do not reflect current 
business practices or modern public financial management. Understanding of, and compliance 
with, existing regulations is also weak. Internal audit is weak, does not have its own mandate, 
and  is  not  actively  involved  in  systems  monitoring.  A  public  expenditure  and  financial 
accountability  assessment  conducted  in  Kiribati  in  2010  identified  weaknesses  in  budget 
accuracy,  significant  delays  and quality  issues  in  recording  and  reporting financial  information, 
and  deficiencies  in  internal  controls  and  audit.  To  mitigate  financial  management  risks,  the 
PMU,  supported  by  a  finance  officer  engaged  under  the  project,  will  ensure  the  accuracy  of 
project  accounts.  Direct  payment  and  reimbursement  procedures  shall  be  used  for  all  works, 
goods,  and  services  except for sanitation  maintenance  contracts  which  will  be  funded  through 
the SMF. 
 
25. 
Procurement capacity. A procurement capacity assessment of MFED and MPWU was 
undertaken, which is included in the PAM. Given identified procurement capacity gaps, ADB will 
administer  selection  of  project  management  and  implementation  consultants.  Procurement  of 
goods and works will be managed by the project support consultant located in the PMU within 
the MFED, with close oversight by ADB. A procurement review for effective implementation will 
be carried out during the midterm review. 
 
26.  Weakly  performing  country.  Kiribati  is  recognized  as  a  fragile  state,  as  described  in 
ADB’s    Achieving    Development    Effectiveness    in    Weakly    Performing    Countries.14
  Factors 
contributing to the country’s fragile situation were assessed and taken into consideration in the 
design of the project. 
 
27. 
Anticorruption. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained 
to,  and  discussed  with,  the  government  and  MFED.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 11). 
 
D. 
 
28. 
The  project  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  provide  social  benefits  through 
improved sanitation and hygiene practices and enhancing access to improved sanitation among 
South Tarawa’s population. This is expected to result in significant health improvements among 
the local population. Improved productivity through a reduction in lost days of work as a result of 
illness  or  caring  for  sick  family  members,  and  reduced  expenditure  on  medical  treatment,  are 
also expected to reduce poverty. 
 
29. 
Gender.  The  project  is  classified  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  majority  of 
project  outputs  have  specific  gender  design  features  to  facilitate  and  ensure  women’s 
participation in, and access to, project benefits. The GAP will ensure that any potentially harmful 
effects  on  women  are  avoided,  with  specific  actions  that  will  allow  women  to  benefit  from  the 
project.  The  GAP  includes  awareness  and  behavior  change  campaigns,  the  recruitment  of 

Poverty and Social

7 

 

 Safeguards 

gender  and  community  engagement  specialists  and  community  mobilizers,  ensuring  women’s 
access to  training opportunities, and gender sensitivity training for PUB and MPWU staff. 
 
E. 
 
30. 
Environment.  The  project  is  classified  as  environment  category  B  under  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  because  it  will  not  result  in  any  significant  environmental 
impacts,  and  all  potential  impacts  can  be  adequately  mitigated  and  monitored.  Initial 
environmental examinations have been prepared for core subproject civil works in accordance 
with the environmental assessment and review framework that has been prepared to guide the 
assessment of subsequent subprojects.15
 The environmental assessment found that the project 
will improve the overall environmental quality of freshwater and nearshore marine areas through 
improved  sewage  and  sanitation  facilities.  Some  impacts  are  expected  near  the  sewerage 
outfalls  but  these  are  expected  to  be  minimal  because  the  outfalls  are  located  more  than  100 
meters  (m)  offshore  and  25  m  deep  to  enable  high  levels  of  dilution.  A  climate  change 
adaptation risk evaluation was conducted and considered in infrastructure design. 
 
31. 
Involuntary  resettlement.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  B  according  to  the 
Safeguard Policy Statement. It is expected to have minimal involuntary resettlement impacts, as 
the  project  facilities  will  be  rehabilitated  on  existing  footprints  mostly  on  government  land. 
Government  lands  that  will  be  used  are  uninhabited  and  devoid  of  crops  and  other  assets. 
However, acquisition of a few parcels of private land and provisions for temporary access and 
use during construction will result in minor resettlement impacts. A resettlement plan has been 
prepared  for  the  sample  subproject  based  on  assessment  of  impacts  and  consultations  with 
affected  persons. 16   A  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared  providing  guidelines  on 
screening,  assessment,  and  preparation  of  resettlement  plans,  if  needed,  for  additional 
subprojects  that  will  be  selected  during  implementation. 17
  Affected  people  and  local 
stakeholders have been consulted and provided with relevant information. 
 
32. 
Indigenous  peoples.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  C.  The  people  of  South 
Tarawa  are from  a  single  ethnic group. There  are  no  customary,  cultural,  economic,  social,  or 
political institutions that set South Tarawa apart from the rest of Kiribati society. 
 
33. 
All safeguard documents have been endorsed by the MFED, the executing agency, and 
disclosed  on  ADB’s  website.  The  project  will  support  the  capacity  of  MFED  and  MPWU,  the 
implementing agency, to manage safeguards. 
 
F.

outweigh the associated risks.
